Document.ChangesMsg1: Thanks for installing Holy Places of the Lord.
Document.ChangesMsg2: You can expect to see these Update messages on a regular basis recapping the latest data updates for temple annoucenments, dedications, groundbreakings and construction updates.
Document.ChangesMsg3: Please check out the Info page by tapping on the info icon on the Home tab.
Document.ChangesMsgQuiz: Hosanna! The Syracuse Utah Temple is dedicated by our beloved prophet Russell M. Nelson! Updated the photos for 120 temples.

Place.Snippet: During the observance of the 150th anniversary of the Church in the British Isles, President Gordon B. Hinckley dedicated a monument near the River Ribble where, on 30 July 1837, the first Latter-day Saint converts were baptized in England. Elder Heber C. Kimball, one of the Twelve Apostles of the Church, baptized six men and three women.

Place.name: Battle of Crooked River Site
Place.Snippet: On October 24, 1838, a skirmish occurred at this place between Church members and the Ray County militia after the militia kidnapped three Saints. The conflict led to casualties on both sides, including Apostle David W. Patten, and was used by Missouri Governor Boggs to justify the "Mormon Extermination Order."

Place.name: Beehive House
Place.Snippet: Built in 1854, this three-story home in downtown Salt Lake City was the official residence of three Presidents of the Church: Brigham Young, Lorenzo Snow, and Joseph F. Smith. It was also used to receive and entertain visitors to the Utah Territory, as Brigham Young was also its governor.

Place.name: Church History Library
Place.Snippet: Completed in 2009, this state-of-the-art facility designed to collect and preserve materials about the Church, its history, and its members contains materials that chronicle the history of the Church from 1830 down to the present day. Many of these materials are available for you to explore.

Place.name: Church History Museum
Place.Snippet: Offers interactive and engaging experiences for individuals and families to discover the history of the church. Exhibits include films, interactive media, fine art, historical artifacts, demonstrations, and activities for children of all ages. Founded in 1984.

Place.name: Church Office Building
Place.Snippet: Home to administrative support staff of the church. Completed in 1972, the 28-story building stands at 420 feet and is the second-tallest building in Salt Lake City. Since it is used as an administrative building, it is not open to the public.

Place.name: Danish Mormon Emigrant Memorial - America Quay
Place.Snippet: Installed on 6 July 2000, this site commemorates the Saints who were among the first Danes to emigrate to America. It features the statue "Kristina", by the American sculptor Dennis Smith, depicting a girl facing a strong wind as she looks out across the North Sea prior to the family's departure. The setts on the promenade beneath the statue are inscribed with about 200 names and the year of their departure.

Place.name: Danish Mormon Emigrant Memorial - Rebild National Park
Place.Snippet: Installed on 4 July 2000, this site commemorates the Saints who were among the first Danes to emigrate to America. It features the statue "The Family", by the American sculptor Dennis Smith, with a mother, a father and three children, and the grandmother, who looks longing back towards her native country. The cobblestones surrounding the statue are inscribed with emigrant names and the year of their departure.

Place.name: Daughters of the Utah Pioneers Museum

Place.name: David Whitmer Grave
Place.Snippet: The last survivor of the Three Witnesses died in Richmond on 25 January 1888 at the age of 83. He and most of his parents' family separated from the Church in 1838 and settled in Richmond. Known as a man of goodness and integrity, he was elected Richmond's mayor in a special election following the death of the prior mayor during a bank robbery.

Place.name: David Whitmer Home Site
Place.Snippet: Although no longer standing, the house at this site was home to the printer's manuscript of the Book of Mormon for decades. Although much of the home was destroyed by a severe storm in 1878, the room wherein the manuscript was kept was untouched.

Place.Snippet: 88th operating temple - Dedicated 11 June 2000 by Gordon B. Hinckley (Announced 7 May 1998)

Place.name: Gadfield Elm Chapel
Place.Snippet: Originally built as a meeting place for the members of the United Brethren congregation who deeded it to the Church after they all converted. In 1840, Brigham Young preached here which, at the time, was the only Latter-day Saint chapel in the world.

Place.name: Gallatin Town Square
Place.Snippet: On 6 August 1838, a mob of 100 people at the election polls in this city attempted to block members of the Church from voting. A brawl followed and several people were injured. When Governor Lilburn W. Boggs heard of this brawl along with other mob activity, he ordered in the state militia to keep the peace. This event is now regarded as the beginning of the "Mormon War".

Place.name: Garden Grove
Place.Snippet: The first temporary way station established in Iowa near the Weldon Fork of the Grand River on April 24, 1846. Many of the Saints’ lives were spared during the harsh first winter thanks to the kindness of their non-member neighbors.

Place.name: Garden Tomb
Place.Snippet: President Harold B. Lee gave special emphasis to the significance of the site. "Something seemed to impress us as we stood there," he said, "that this was the holiest place of all, and we fancied we could have witnessed the dramatic scene that took place there."

Place.name: Gethsemane
Place.Snippet: The likely place where Jesus prayed and suffered for the sins of mankind. In Aramaic, it means 'olive press.' Oil is still pressed from the fruit of eight ancient and gnarled olive trees that give the garden a timeless character.

Place.name: Gilbert Arizona Temple
Place.Snippet: 142nd operating temple - Dedicated 2 March 2014 by Thomas S. Monson read by Henry B. Eyring (Announced 26 April 2008)

Place.name: Gilgal Sculpture Garden
Place.Snippet: Designed and created in the mid-twentieth century by Thomas Child, Jr to fulfill his desire to give physical form to his deep-felt beliefs. Contains 12 original sculptures and over 70 stones engraved with scriptures, poems, and literary texts.

Place.name: Goiãnia Brazil Temple
Place.Snippet: Announced 1 October 2023 - Status: Planning and approval phase; awaiting official site announcement

Place.name: Haun's Mill
Place.Snippet: Early latter-day saint settlement on Shoal Creek. Site of the most savage massacre that occurred during the Missouri troubles.

Place.name: Heber C. Kimball Nauvoo Home
Place.Snippet: The brick home that the family occupied less than a year before they were forced to leave and faithfully gathered with the Saints for the westward trek. First restored home in the area.

Place.name: Hill Cumorah
Place.Snippet: The golden plates were buried here by Moroni. A granite monument topped by a nine-foot statue of Moroni was erected at the highest point of the hill in 1935.

Place.name: Hill Cumorah Visitors' Center
Place.Snippet: Learn about the events that occurred on and near the Hill Cumorah in the 1820s.

Place.name: Hill Farm and Benbow's Pond
Place.Snippet: At this site on March 6th, 1840, Wilford Woodruff baptized the first of the 600 converts from the United Brethren's congregation and 45 additional converts were baptized through 1841. A marker was erected in 1987 to commemorate the sesquicentennial of the Church in the British Isles.

Place.name: Hiram Page Grave
Place.Snippet: This roadside burial plot is the grave of one of the Eight Witnesses to the Book of Mormon, who died 12 August 1852. The plot was, at the time of his passing, on his farm. Although he left the Church during the tumultuous 1830s he never denied his testimony. His son Philander said, in 1888, "I knew my father to be true and faithful to his testimony of the divinity of the Book of Mormon until the very last."

Place.name: Hong Kong China Temple
Place.Snippet: 48th operating temple - Dedicated 26–27 May 1996 by Gordon B. Hinckley (Announced 3 October 1992); Rededicated 19 June 2022 by Gerrit W. Gong

Place.Snippet: This functioning chapel was recently remodeled to include a variety of exhibits on principles of the gospel of Jesus Christ, temples, and the history of The Church in the British Isles.

Place.name: Icelandic Monument
Place.Snippet: Dedicated In 1938, this replica of a lighthouse commemorates the first permanent settlement in the United States of this people. Includes a viking ship on top with the 16 original immigrants’ names etched into the monument

Place.name: Idaho Falls Idaho Temple
Place.Snippet: 8th operating temple - Dedicated 23–25 September 1945 by George Albert Smith (Announced 3 March 1937); Rededicated 4 June 2017 by Henry B. Eyring

Place.Snippet: Enjoy the reflection of the Idaho Falls Idaho Temple in the nearby Snake River.

Place.name: Isaac and Elizabeth Hale Home
Place.Snippet: This reconstructed home, built at its original location, offers a glimpse into Emma’s life as a child and as a young woman. You will also see the place where Joseph began translating the Book of Mormon.

Place.name: Isaac Morley Farm
Place.Snippet: Served as the principle gathering place of the Saints in Kirtland after the revelation for the Saints to gather to Ohio.

Place.name: Isaac Russell Gravesite
Place.Snippet: An early convert to the Church, and a faithful Elder in the first group of missionaries to England, is buried near this site in an unmarked grave. Although he never denied his faith, he was among those excommunicated when the apostles returned to Far West on 26 April 1839. His widow and adult children migrated to Utah in 1861.

Place.name: Jacob Hamblin Home
Place.Snippet: Home of the man who was called "Friend of the Indians." See what life was like for a large family in a frontier town.

Place.name: Jacksonville Florida Temple
Place.Snippet: Announced 2 October 2022 - Status: Planning and approval phase; site location announced; exterior rendering released; groundbreaking not announced

Place.Address: Synthesis Square, Jalan Gatot Subroto, No. 177A

Place.Snippet: Announced 1 October 2023 - Status: Planning and approval phase; site location announced; exterior rendering released; groundbreaking not announced
Place.Address: Rua Paulino Pinto and Avenida Ministro José Américo de Almeida

Place.name: Johannesburg South Africa Temple
Place.Snippet: 36th operating temple - Dedicated 24–25 August 1985 by Gordon B. Hinckley (Announced 1 April 1981)

Place.name: John Johnson Home
Place.Snippet: During the year Joseph Smith stayed here, this home served as headquarters of the Church and he received an outpouring of revelation within these walls. Several conferences were also held here.

Place.name: John Taylor Family Farm
Place.Snippet: In 1992, Europe North Area President, Elder Jeffrey R. Holland, dedicated a plaque marking John Taylor’s boyhood home. It is situated just outside the fence in front of the privately owned house.

Place.name: John Taylor Nauvoo Home
Place.Snippet: One of the earliest brick homes in Nauvoo. This beautiful federal-style home was built by John Ivins and later occupied by a future prophet and his family.

Place.name: John Whitmer Grave
Place.Snippet: One of the Eight Witnesses to the Book of Mormon is buried here. Remaining in Missouri following the Saints' exodus from Missouri in 1839, he eventually held title to the temple site property at Far West and is credited with preserving the site. He died on 11 July 1878.

Place.name: Johnson Inn Resource Center
Place.Snippet: Gain a wealth of information about the Kirtland area by visiting this reconstruction with exhibits that serve as a reminder of the rich heritage of Kirtland.

Place.name: Jonathan Browning Nauvoo Home and Gun Shop
Place.Snippet: Learn about the humble beginnings of the worldwide Browning Arms Corporation. See authentic rifles, handguns, and shotguns from the early 1800s.

Place.name: Jordan River Utah Temple
Place.Snippet: 20th operating temple - Dedicated 16–20 November 1981 by Marion G. Romney (Announced 3 February 1978); Rededicated 20 May 2018 by Henry B. Eyring

Place.name: Joseph and Emma Smith Kirtland Home
Place.Snippet: The home where the prophet and his wife lived for longer than anywhere else (over four years). First hymnal, second edition of the Book of Mormon and first edition of the Doctrine and Covenants were compiled here.

Place.name: Joseph and Emma Smith Susquehanna Home
Place.Snippet: Reconstructed at its original location, this home is where Emma gave birth to her first child. Joseph translated most of the Book of Mormon here, with Oliver Cowdery and others acting as scribes.

Place.name: Joseph Knight Home
Place.Snippet: The Colesville Branch, established as the first branch of the Church in September of 1830, met in this prominent member's home which has been lovingly restored over 12 years by members in the area and opened for daily tours in 2016.

Place.name: Joseph Smith Birthplace Memorial
Place.Snippet: The smooth polished obelisk shaft is 38 1/2 feet tall, one foot for each year of the Prophet's life. A visitor's center provides further information.

Place.name: Joseph Smith Historic Site
Place.Snippet: Closed until further notice since it changed ownership to our church. Guided walking tours would begin at this Visitors Center through the Smith family’s homes.

Place.name: Joseph Smith Memorial Building
Place.Snippet: Formerly the Hotel Utah, was built in 1911. Completely renovated and reopened in 1993, now provides dining options and event hosting with restaurants, large meeting rooms, and banquet and wedding reception rooms. The building is also home to a 500-seat theater that hosts various film experiences.

Place.name: Joseph Standing Monument
Place.Snippet: Dedicated by David O. McKay on May 3, 1952, it honors the memory of a Utah missionary who was killed by an armed mob of a dozen men on July 21, 1879. This was his second mission for the Church and he was serving as the presiding Elder of the Georgia Conference.

Place.name: Josiah Stowell Home
Place.Snippet: Beautifully restored home of the man who brought Joseph Smith to the area for work where Joseph met his future wife Emma Hale. The grounds now feature a statue of a young Joseph Smith.

Place.name: Juchitán de Zaragoza Mexico Temple
Place.Snippet: Announced 6 October 2024 - Status: Planning and approval phase; awaiting official site announcement

Place.name: Kanesville Tabernacle
Place.Snippet: Now serves as a visitors' center, where you can learn more about the epic history of the Latter-day Saints' migration westward.

Place.name: Kansas City Missouri Temple
Place.Snippet: 137th operating temple - Dedicated 6 May 2012 by Thomas S. Monson (Announced 4 October 2008)

Place.name: Kaohsiung Taiwan Temple
Place.Snippet: Announced 3 October 2021 - Status: Groundbreaking 25 November 2023; Steeple frame installed; roofs added to ancillary buildings; ETC late 2026 to early 2027

Place.name: Kimball-Whitney Cemetery
Place.Snippet: The cemetery, originally owned by Heber C. Kimball and Newel K. Whitney, was one of the first in the Salt Lake Valley. Whitney was buried there three years after the Saints’ arrival, and Kimball and his wife were buried there eighteen years later.

Place.name: Kinshasa Democratic Republic of the Congo Temple
Place.Snippet: 163rd operating temple - Dedicated 14 April 2019 by Dale G. Renlund (Announced 1 October 2011)
Place.Address: 50 Avenue de L'OUA, Quartier Basoko, GB

Place.name: Kirtland Ashery
Place.Snippet: Gain insight into this unique industry in providing the financial means to build the temple and other Church buildings.

Place.name: Kirtland Camp - Yellow Creek
Place.Snippet: On 27 September 1838, the main body of Kirtland Camp arrived here and spent the night before traveling on to Shoal Creek. The group's journal stated the area had been set aside for military purposes, and was therefore uninhabited.
Place.Address: Slater Ave. and County Rd. E

Place.name: Kirtland Camp – Mooresville
Place.Snippet: In 1838, the presidency of the Seventy in Kirtland, Ohio, organized Kirtland Camp to help more than 500 Saints of meager means migrate to Missouri. Nearing the end of their three-month, 800-mile journey the Saints camped here before travelling on to Far West, and finally on to Adam-Ondi-Ahman, where they arrived on 4 October 1838.

Place.name: Kirtland Temple
Place.Snippet: The first temple erected in this dispensation. The design for this holy edifice was received by detailed revelation to the Prophet Joseph Smith and others.

Place.name: Kirtland Sawmill
Place.Snippet: This reconstructed building demonstrates how timber was cut in the 1830s. This mill cut much of the timber for the woodwork in the Kirtland Temple.

Place.name: Kirtland Schoolhouse
Place.Snippet: Replica of the original built on this spot in 1819. This was a center of activity and, on Sundays, the Saints often met here for Church meetings.

Place.name: Kirtland Visitors' Center
Place.Snippet: Historic Kirtland, a small settlement in northern Ohio where members gathered shortly after the Church was founded.

Place.name: Martin and Lucy Harris Farm
Place.Snippet: This 320 acre property near Palmyra, New York, was significant in the history of the church. In 1829, Harris mortgaged his farm to publish 5,000 copies of the book and later sold 151 acres to settle the debt. In 1937, 88 acres of the farm, including the site of the original farmhouse, were acquired by the church.

Place.name: Martin Harris Gravesite
Place.Snippet: One of the Three Witnesses of the Book of Mormon, came to Utah in 1870 at the age of 87 and settled in Clarkston, Utah, where he died on July 10, 1875.

Place.name: Mormon Battalion Monument
Place.Snippet: The 100-foot granite and bronze monument honors the sacrifice made by the hundreds of Latter-day Saint pioneers who joined the U.S. Army during the Mexican War. Located on southeast lawn.

Place.name: Mormon Battalion Monument - Tucson
Place.Snippet: Dedicated by Gordon B. Hinckley on December 14, 1996 on the sesquicentennial of this peaceful exchange between the anglo-american and hispanic cultures and the beginning of U.S. influence in the Southwest.
Place.Address: El Presidio Park, 160 W Alameda St

Place.name: Mormon Battalion Monument - New Mexico
Place.Snippet: Impressive monument honoring the heroic march of 500 men across a harsh wilderness. Originally dedicated in June 1846 and rededicated in this new location in September 1996.

Place.name: Mormon Battalion Monument - Yuma
Place.Snippet: Erected in 2007 to honor the sacrifice of the 500 men who arrived at and crossed the Colorado River with 'extreme suffering'. The crossing was particularly challenging for the soldiers and it took a considerable while for all to get across the river.

Place.name: Mormon Handcart
Place.Snippet: Relax and enjoy the artwork, artifacts, and exhibits at the welcome center. Before venturing further, missionaries will show a brief video about the handcart pioneers. The trail to Martin’s Cove starts here and covers 5 miles to the upper reaches and back. You can arrange with missionaries to pull a handcart for the first 1.25 miles.

Place.name: Mormon Handcart Park
Place.Snippet: A beautiful site where flora and fauna remained preserved in their natural state. A cooperative effort between the University of Iowa and the Church in which historical interpretation of the handcart outfitting stations is provided.
Place.Address: The University of Iowa, Hawkeye Ct

Place.name: Mormon Pioneer Memorial Monument
Place.Snippet: Dedicated to the more than 6,000 souls who died making the journey to Utah from Illinois and other parts of the world between 1847 and 1869. It is also contains the gravesite of Brigham Young and other early Latter-day Saint leaders.

Place.name: Mormon Trail Center
Place.Snippet: Witness the great "Mormon Migration" as you walk beside a covered wagon, pull a handcart and climb in the bunks on a steam ship. Adjacent to the Winter Quarters grave yard and memorial.

Place.name: Moses Lake Washington Temple
Place.Snippet: 182nd operating temple - Dedicated 17 September 2023 by Quentin L. Cook (Announced 7 April 2019)

Place.name: Mount Pisgah
Place.Snippet: Established in southern Iowa as a temporary way station for Latter-day Saint emigrants who crossed the Plains from 1846-1852. The picturesque setting was a welcome sight to many of the expelled Saints.

Place.name: Mount Timpanogos Utah Temple
Place.Snippet: 49th operating temple - Dedicated 13–19 October 1996 by Gordon B. Hinckley (Announced 3 October 1992)

Place.name: Mountain Meadows Monument
Place.Snippet: Monument remembering the 120 emigrants who were tragically massacred in September of 1857 by local militia members. A solemn reminder of how bad decisions and misunderstanding can lead to tragic results.

Place.name: Museum of Mormon History of the Americas
Place.Snippet: Preserves an extensive collection of artifacts from early Latter-day Saints in Latin America. It is unique, inspiring, faith promoting, historical and uplifting.

Place.name: Nauvoo Cultural Hall
Place.Snippet: Also known as the Masonic Hall, this stately building was the scene not only of theatricals and meetings of the Masonic Lodge but also of court sessions and funerals. It was used as a wagon shop when preparing for the trek west.

Place.name: Nauvoo Family Living Center

Place.name: Nauvoo Post Office

Place.name: Nauvoo Visitors' Center

Following the command that begun with "Silence, ye fiends of the infernal pit...", the guards begged his pardon, and remained silent.

Place.name: Seventies Hall
Place.Snippet: First MTC and library, where men and women once gathered to listen to Brigham Young and other Church leaders. The building now houses a museum of household artifacts.

Place.name: Shumway Schoolhouse
Place.Snippet: Built in Northern Arizona in 1900 of fired brick. Served 20-25 students in grades from 1-8. Also served as a social center for weddings, funerals, dances and church services until 1948.
Place.Address: Shumway Rd (0.2 mi. east of AZ Rte 77)

Place.name: Singapore Temple

Place.name: Sixth Crossing
Place.Snippet: This Visitors' Center was dedicated June 15, 2017 as a tribute to the pioneers of the ill-fated Willie and Martin handcart companies. Experience a trek on the Sweetwater trail.

Place.name: Smith Brothers Release Site
Place.Snippet: On 16 April 1839, Joseph and Hyrum Smith, other prisoners from Liberty Jail, and their guards were camping on the east side of East Yellow Creek on their way to trial in Columbia. After providing the prisoners horses and supplies, the sheriff said, "I shall take a good drink of grog and go to bed, and you may do as you have a mind to," allowing his prisoners "escape" to Illinois.
Place.Address: Slater Ave. and County Rd. E

Place.name: Smith Family Farm
Place.Snippet: This area begins at the Welcome Center where tours include the Smith's first log home, their second frame home, a cooper shop and threshing barn. This was the setting for several important events relating to the coming forth of the Book of Mormon.

Place.name: Smith Family Homestead
Place.Snippet: This cabin on the river became Joseph and Emma's first home in Nauvoo. The Smith Family Cemetery is located here as well.

Place.name: Smith Family Memorial
Place.Snippet: Two monuments in Topsfield, Massachusetts in honor of several of Joseph Smith Jr.'s ancestors. First one erected in 1873 by George A. Smith; Second larger one in 2020 by the Ensign Peak Foundation.

Place.name: Smithfield Utah Temple

Place.name: Snowﬂake Monument
Place.Snippet: Portrays a trailside meeting in September 1878 of William J. Flake and Elder Erastus Snow which impacted generations to come as it helped establish this northern Arizona town.
Place.Address: South Main Street and West 1st Street

Place.Snippet: Dedicated in 1876 after more than a decade under construction, it is known as the "Jewel of the West". Best known for the place where President Lorenzo Snow received a revelation that the Saints needed to be more faithful in paying their tithes and offerings.

Place.name: Temple Square
Place.Snippet: As Utah’s most visited attraction, a historic center of worship located in downtown Salt Lake City. It spans five city blocks (35 acres), featuring engaging exhibits, wholesome activities, and beautiful gardens. Currently undergoing a major renovation that will dramatically transform this iconic space.

Place.name: Temple Square North Visitors' Center
Place.Snippet: Was built in 1963 and featured art exhibits, exhibits about the Church, and film experiences, with a replica of Bertel Thorvaldsen's Christus as its centerpiece. -- Was demolished in 2021 as part of the Temple Square renovation project and replaced with open gardens and a restroom facility.

Place.name: Temple Square South Visitors' Center
Place.Snippet: Was built in 1963 and specifically focused on the Salt Lake Temple, showcasing its history and significance and featured a replica of the temple. -- Was demolished in 2019 and is being replaced with two new guest and visitor pavilions.

Place.name: This Is the Place Monument

Place.name: Three Forks Settlement
Place.Snippet: In the spring of 1838, about 145 Saints settled this area but in August of that year, Joseph Smith and other Church leaders visited and advised the Saints to gather in Far West. However, Joseph told them that "Here will be one of the stakes of Zion."

Place.name: Tinney Grove
Place.Snippet: This small village in northeastern Ray County was settled by Nathan and Mary Jane Tinney, members of the Church who did not gather at Far West. It was a way station for many as they fled the state partly because it is in Buncombe's Strip - an agreed-upon neutral zone between Ray and Caldwell Counties.

Place.Snippet: Visit this peaceful site on a 52-acre hilltop with woods, specimen trees, and beautiful flower gardens.

Place.name: Webb Brothers Blacksmith Shop
Place.Snippet: Learn how wagon wheels were constructed. Each family who visits receives a mini horseshoe.

Place.name: Weber County Daughters of Utah Pioneers Musuem
Place.Snippet: Originally dedicated in 1902 this historic building is the only known Stake Relief Society hall built by the Church. It was moved from its original location in 2012 to make space for the rebuilt Ogden Temple. It has a large section that is dedicated specifically to the pioneer journey.

Place.name: Welfare Square
Place.Snippet: A tour of this place serves as both a history lesson and a reminder of the Church’s mission to "care for the poor, foster self-reliance, and provide meaningful opportunities for work and service."

Place.name: William and Caroline Weeks Home
Place.Snippet: Home of the architect that Joseph Smith selected for the Nauvoo temple in 1841 after calling for design proposals and liking his initial ideas best. Parlor used to showcase design options for clients.

Place.name: William and Ester Gheen Home
Place.Snippet: He died at home in 1845 before the Nauvoo Temple was completed. His wife was able to be sealed to him by proxy in the temple on February 2, 1846. This fulfilled their desire for their family to be together forever.

Place.name: Zion's Camp Miracle at Fishing River
Place.Snippet: On 18 June 1834, Zion's Camp was miraculously protected from a mob of about 400 armed men when a storm suddenly flooded the two forks of the Fishing River, making the area impassable. As the storm appeared, Joseph Smith said, "Boys, there is some meaning to this, God is in this storm."
